      76             : namespace cereal
      77             : {
      78             :   // ######################################################################
      79             :   //! An output archive designed to save data to JSON
      80             :   /*! This archive uses RapidJSON to build serialize data to JSON.
      81             : 
      82             :       JSON archives provides a human readable output but at decreased
      83             :       performance (both in time and space) compared to binary archives.
      84             : 
      85             :       JSON archives are only guaranteed to finish flushing their contents
      86             :       upon destruction and should thus be used in an RAII fashion.
      87             : 
      88             :       JSON benefits greatly from name-value pairs, which if present, will
      89             :       name the nodes in the output.  If these are not present, each level
      90             :       of the output will be given an automatically generated delimited name.
      91             : 
      92             :       The precision of the output archive controls the number of decimals output
      93             :       for floating point numbers and should be sufficiently large (i.e. at least 20)
      94             :       if there is a desire to have binary equality between the numbers output and
      95             :       those read in.  In general you should expect a loss of precision when going
      96             :       from floating point to text and back.
      97             : 
      98             :       JSON archives do not output the size information for any dynamically sized structure
      99             :       and instead infer it from the number of children for a node.  This means that data
     100             :       can be hand edited for dynamic sized structures and will still be readable.  This
     101             :       is accomplished through the cereal::SizeTag object, which will cause the archive
     102             :       to output the data as a JSON array (e.g. marked by [] instead of {}), which indicates
     103             :       that the container is variable sized and may be edited.
     104             : 
     105             :       \ingroup Archives */
     106             : #ifdef __SIZEOF_INT128__
     107             :   namespace int128_support {
     108             :       // In order to correctly identify GCC and clang we must either:
     109             :       // 1. use "#if defined(__GNUC__) && !defined(__clang__)" (preferred option)
     110             :       // 2. or check the condition "#if defined __clang__" first
     111             :       // The reason is: clang always defines __GNUC__ and __GNUC_MINOR__ and __GNUC_PATCHLEVEL__ according to
     112             :       // the version of gcc that it claims full compatibility with.

     376             :       //! Write the name of the upcoming node and prepare object/array state
     377             :       /*! Since writeName is called for every value that is output, regardless of
     378             :           whether it has a name or not, it is the place where we will do a deferred
     379             :           check of our node state and decide whether we are in an array or an object.
     380             : 
     381             :           The general workflow of saving to the JSON archive is:
     382             : 
     383             :             1. (optional) Set the name for the next node to be created, usually done by an NVP
     384             :             2. Start the node
     385             :             3. (if there is data to save) Write the name of the node (this function)
     386             :             4. (if there is data to save) Save the data (with saveValue)
     387             :             5. Finish the node
     388             :           */

     433             :       std::stack<NodeType> itsNodeStack;
     434             :   }; // JSONOutputArchive
     435             : 
     436             :   // ######################################################################
     437             :   //! An input archive designed to load data from JSON
     438             :   /*! This archive uses RapidJSON to read in a JSON archive.
     439             : 
     440             :       As with the output JSON archive, the preferred way to use this archive is in
     441             :       an RAII fashion, ensuring its destruction after all data has been read.
     442             : 
     443             :       Input JSON should have been produced by the JSONOutputArchive.  Data can
     444             :       only be added to dynamically sized containers (marked by JSON arrays) -
     445             :       the input archive will determine their size by looking at the number of child nodes.
     446             :       Only JSON originating from a JSONOutputArchive is officially supported, but data
     447             :       from other sources may work if properly formatted.
     448             : 
     449             :       The JSONInputArchive does not require that nodes are loaded in the same
     450             :       order they were saved by JSONOutputArchive.  Using name value pairs (NVPs),
     451             :       it is possible to load in an out of order fashion or otherwise skip/select
     452             :       specific nodes to load.
     453             : 
     454             :       The default behavior of the input archive is to read sequentially starting
     455             :       with the first node and exploring its children.  When a given NVP does
     456             :       not match the read in name for a node, the archive will search for that
     457             :       node at the current level and load it if it exists.  After loading an out of
     458             :       order node, the archive will then proceed back to loading sequentially from
     459             :       its new position.
     460             : 
     461             :       Consider this simple example where loading of some data is skipped:
     462             : 
     463             :       @code{cpp}
     464             :       // imagine the input file has someData(1-9) saved in order at the top level node
     465             :       ar( someData1, someData2, someData3 );        // XML loads in the order it sees in the file
     466             :       ar( cereal::make_nvp( "hello", someData6 ) ); // NVP given does not
     467             :                                                     // match expected NVP name, so we search
     468             :                                                     // for the given NVP and load that value
     469             :       ar( someData7, someData8, someData9 );        // with no NVP given, loading resumes at its
     470             :                                                     // current location, proceeding sequentially
     471             :       @endcode
     472             : 
     473             :       \ingroup Archives */
     474             :   class JSONInputArchive : public InputArchive<JSONInputArchive>, public traits::TextArchive
     475             :   {
     476             :     private:
     477             :       using ReadStream = CEREAL_RAPIDJSON_NAMESPACE::IStreamWrapper;
     478             :       typedef CEREAL_RAPIDJSON_NAMESPACE::GenericValue<CEREAL_RAPIDJSON_NAMESPACE::UTF8<>> JSONValue;
     479             :       typedef JSONValue::ConstMemberIterator MemberIterator;
     480             :       typedef JSONValue::ConstValueIterator ValueIterator;

     611             :       //! Searches for the expectedName node if it doesn't match the actualName
     612             :       /*! This needs to be called before every load or node start occurs.  This function will
     613             :           check to see if an NVP has been provided (with setNextName) and if so, see if that name matches the actual
     614             :           next name given.  If the names do not match, it will search in the current level of the JSON for that name.

     638             :     public:

     640             :       /*! This places an iterator for the next node to be parsed onto the iterator stack.  If the next
     641             :           node is an array, this will be a value iterator, otherwise it will be a member iterator.
     642             : 
     643             :           By default our strategy is to start with the document root node and then recursively iterate through
     644             :           all children in the order they show up in the document.
     645             :           We don't need to know NVPs to do this; we'll just blindly load in the order things appear in.

     647             :           If we were given an NVP, we will search for it if it does not match our the name of the next node
